name: Black vs Flank & Irregular Openings
description: A practical repertoire against rare but annoying club-level weapons: 1.g3, 1.b3, 1.f4, 1.b4, 1.Nc3, 1.g4, and other irregular openings. Our strategy: Don't panic! These openings are offbeat for a reason - solid central play gives us comfortable positions. We're not looking for refutations, just sensible development that punishes White's lack of central presence.

tree.explanation: Welcome to the world of flank and irregular openings! White is avoiding main lines, but that doesn't mean we should. Classical central play is usually the best response.

children.explanation: The Benko Opening (King's Fianchetto)! White prepares to fianchetto without committing to anything else. Flexible but slow - we can grab the center!
THE CLASSICAL RESPONSE! We occupy the center immediately. This often transposes to Réti or Catalan structures where we're well-prepared from our 1.c4 repertoire.
White fianchettoes.
We develop naturally.
White develops.
OUR SLAV SETUP! We support d5 and prepare ...Bf5. If White plays c4 and d4, we're in familiar Slav territory!
White castles.
THE KEY MOVE! Bishop out before e6. Same Slav philosophy!
White plays solidly.
We solidify. Now we can develop ...Be7 and castle. Very comfortable position!
White develops.
We develop. Ready to castle with a great position - bishop is already active!
White plans e4.
We castle. Black has easy play and no weaknesses.
White strikes.
We retreat to safety. The bishop is still useful on h7.
White plays c4 - transposes to Réti/English territory!
We solidify. This is our familiar anti-English/Réti setup! See Black vs 1.c4 repertoire for similar structures.
White plays c4 early - English/Réti transposition!
Bishop out! Same plan - this is our Réti setup from the 1.c4 repertoire.
White plays d4 - now we're in Queen's Pawn territory!
Bishop out first! If c4, we're in the Slav. If not, we have a great Catalan/London setup.
Alternative - more solid but locks in the bishop.

Our Slav setup! This is identical to 1.Nf3 d5 2.g3 Nf6 3.Bg2 c6 - see 1.c4 repertoire for full coverage.

THE CLASSICAL RESPONSE! We grab the center. White's Bb2 will be blocked by our e5 pawn!

The Bird's Opening! White controls e5 and prepares a kingside fianchetto. The weakness? White's king is exposed and e4 is weak!
FROM'S GAMBIT! The most aggressive response - we sacrifice a pawn for rapid development and attack. Very dangerous for White if unprepared!
White accepts. Most common.
THE KEY MOVE! We attack e5 and prepare to bring the bishop to c5, targeting f2 - the weakest point!
